value: There are many old wooden buildings in Chiang Khan.

(เชียงคาน) is a small town in Loei Province of Thailand's
region. It sits on the south bank of the Mekong River facing the Lao town of
Day and night buses run direct from Bangkok's Mo Chit bus station. The nearest train station is at Nong Khai (on the Lao border), from where there are also buses available to Chiang Khan.

Chiang Khan is a small town and easily seen on foot. There are basically two streets: Chai Kong, which is by the river and where most of the guesthouses are, and Sri Chiang Khan, which is the main road. Both streets run parallel to the river for a couple of kilometres. If you plan to visit the Kaeng Khut Khu rapids, which are well worth checking out, you can travel the 5 km by tuk-tuk for around 50 baht each way, or hire a bike.

value: The dazzling lights of the evening entertainment.

Most people come to Chiang Khan to see the serenity of life lived at a slower pace. The best things to see are the old buildings and their seemingly untroubled inhabitants. Cap a busy day's idling by watching the sun set over the Mekong. If you need to see a temple, Wat Si Khun Mueang will satisfy.

content=Scenic cataracts and rapids. Cycle, go by boat trip or tuk-tuk.

There are a few riverside handicrafts stalls near the pier and there's a 7-Eleven on a road parallel to the main street.
The local cuisine is heavily influenced by Lao flavours.
There are several basic guesthouses. Including:
